description.plain:
Arctic Monkeys is an English rock band formed in 2002 in High Green, a suburb of Sheffield, England. The band consists of Alex Turner (lead vocals, rhythm/lead guitar), Matt Helders (drums, vocals), Jamie Cook (lead/rhythm guitar) and Nick O'Malley (bass, backing vocals). Former band member Andy Nicholson (bass guitar, backing vocals) left the band in 2006 shortly after their debut album was released. Their sound has changed extensively from album to album, gradually evolving from raw, youthful post-punk revival music to R ‘n’ B and jazz-inspired experiments.

All four original members of the band were devoted fans of hip-hop when they were younger, a genre that would have an immense influence on their later work, but it was the sound of The Strokes and The Libertines that would help shape their early style. The Arctic Monkeys became one of the first bands to find fame and recognition purely through internet publicity and social media; the Arctics used to sell their demos CDs at a bar where Alex Turner used to work, but due to the limited number of CDs, their fans started to upload them on the internet.

Initially, they refused to sign a record contract with any label through fear that they would want the band to change their songs, going as far as to refuse scouts guaranteed entry into their gigs. However, they eventually signed with Domino because of the “do it yourself” attitude of founder, Lawrence Bell, who ran the label from his own house.

The group released their scrappy, spirited debut Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not in 2006, an album that spawned their first UK No. 1 singles, “I Bet You Look Good on the Dancefloor” and “When the Sun Goes Down”. They followed it up with Favourite Worst Nightmare in 2007, which took on a more mature lyrical direction, with tighter, more accessible hooks and melodies and more polished production. Their most accessible album to date is AM, which contains some of their catchiest and most notable singles, including the indie hit “Do I Wanna Know?.”

Arctic Monkeys subsequently took a five-year break from releasing albums, before returning with their polarising sixth studio album Tranquility Base Hotel and Casino in 2018.

songs.title: Do I Wanna Know?

description.plain:
“Do I Wanna Know” is the first single from AM, premiered live at the Ventura Theatre, CA on May 22, 2013.

In it, Alex portrays himself as an obsessive lover that is paranoid about the state of his relationship.

songs.full_title: 505 by Arctic Monkeys

description.plain:
“505” is one of the songs that marks a turning point in Alex Turner’s songwriting, as he discovers new emotional depths.

The organ chords are the same as were used in Ennio Morricone’s soundtrack for the iconic Western, The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, where Angel Eyes enters before the final standoff.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sXldafIl5DQ

The title could be an allusion to “Flight 505” by The Rolling Stones, with both songs sharing the theme of going somewhere to recapture a feeling or moment… or a person.

songs.full_title: Fluorescent Adolescent by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Fluorescent Adolescent

description.plain:
“Fluorescent Adolescent” is a ballad about getting older and finding out that life isn’t as fun anymore. It describes a woman who dreams of her youth while her current life is unsatisfying and boring, with emphasis on her sex life.

The song is one of the band’s most popular and a concert staple.

The writing of this is co-credited to Johanna Bennett, Alex Turner’s ex-girlfriend. The song’s roots lie in a Mediterranean holiday Turner and Bennett took during which they were reminiscing about characters they knew at school, as he recalled in The Times magazine in 2007 (documented by NME magazine):

It started off as a joke. Then it were like, “Here’s another verse.” We were having a laugh. Some of the lines were hers. I couldn’t have not credited her. It’s just right, really.

As documented by NME magazine, Johanna herself said during an interview for The Observer that:


We were on holiday and had cut ourselves off from everything. We were in a really quiet hotel and didn’t watch TV or listen to that much music… So as not to drive each other mad we started messing around with these words like game, singing them to each other.

It’s great to think that it came from something we did for fun on holiday. It’ll always be a good memory for Alex and I. He doesn’t usually write lyrics with other people, though I think he enjoyed it.

songs.full_title: I Wanna Be Yours by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: I Wanna Be Yours

description.plain:
The song reworks John Cooper Clarke’s poem of the same name. The song focuses on similar themes in the poem. In an interview, Clarke said his poem is:

one of a classic style of love poem, love song, in which the writer expresses his desire to be useful to the object of his desire.

The beat is strongly reminiscent of “Spanish Sahara.”
Reworking a poem into a song is extremely difficult and as John Cooper Clarke put it Alex has changed a semi-comedic poem into a full-on love song. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0jkiz8R1VyI

songs.full_title: R U Mine? by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: R U Mine?

description.plain:
A single from Arctic Monkeys originally released in early 2012 for Record Store Day in the UK. “R U Mine?” was then re-recorded for their 2013 album AM.

The song delves into the relationship between casual flirtation and addictive lust, with Alex describing himself as just a “puppet” for her, completely under her control and compulsively begging for her affection.

songs.full_title: Knee Socks by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Knee Socks

description.plain:
Perhaps the album’s best song is tucked away just before it ends. Everything about this track is sexy…from the bass drum and simple guitar riff as it opens, to the imagery conjured up by a line like “When you walked around your house wearing my sky blue Lacoste… And your knee socks". And we’re bouncing as the images in Alex’s head come together in a parting crescendo.

Here’s a live version with Homme.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ykd_jrqDdjI

songs.full_title: No. 1 Party Anthem by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: No. 1 Party Anthem

description.plain:
Ironically, the slowest track off of AM, “No. 1 Party Anthem,” pokes fun at waiting for an anthemic party song to feel the vibe. Some of the lyrics here were first used on Arctic Monkeys greatest hit, “Do I Wanna Know?,” as Alex Turner commented:

Actually, I was looking through my old voice memos on my iPhone this morning, and I found a demo for “Do I Wanna Know?” that I’ve done, and it’s got the lyrics from “No. 1 Party Anthem” on it.

VIA UNDER THE RADAR MAGAZINE

songs.full_title: Four Out of Five by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Four Out of Five

description.plain:
The song describes advertising for the titular Tranquility Base Hotel & Casino. Some parts read explicitly like an advert, inviting the listener to come and relax at Tranquility Base. The lyrics are set within the universe of the album, describing the new businesses being set up on the Lunar surface and all the potential lovely experiences one might have there, and showing off a good review given to the taqueria: four stars out of five.

The hook also details the meaning behind the Tranquility Base Hotel & Casino’s location, and the space themed narrative begins to unfold.

This song was debuted live before the release of the album with assistance from Tame Impala member Cameron Avery.

songs.full_title: Star Treatment by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Star Treatment

description.plain:
“Star Treatment” is the opener to the Arctic Monkeys' sixth studio album, co-produced by Alex Turner himself for the first time.

Throughout the song, Turner covers his past turmoils and inspirations before the fame, with a rich and meticulously crafted metaphor for how idolized celebrities are distorted by the media similar to the light of a star. The track also uses introspection to pay homage to icons such as The Strokes and Leonard Cohen.

songs.title: Tranquility Base Hotel & Casino

description.plain:
The title track and fourth song off the Tranquility Base Hotel & Casino by the British rock band, Arctic Monkeys.

The song uses conceptual and political imagery to give the listener a firsthand view of the “Casino” and its features.

A couple of months after the album’s release, the track was released as the second and final single for the LP.

songs.full_title: Suck It and See by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Suck It and See

description.plain: “Suck It and See” is a song about having an almost unhealthy affection for someone (“Your love is like a studded leather headlock/Be cruel to me, ‘cause I’m a fool for you”). It’s rather romantic but doesn’t stick to the usual clichés. Alex uses very creative metaphors, similes and other techniques to combine the beauty of a classic love song and reinvent it. It is the title track from Arctic Monkeys’ fourth album.

songs.full_title: Cornerstone by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Cornerstone

description.plain:
“Cornerstone” is the seventh track of Arctic Monkeys’ 2009 release Humbug, and the second single to be released from the album.

The song has a straightforward narrative. The narrator visits several different pubs, and finds at each venue a woman who resembles the ex-lover he’s pining for. He approaches the women, but is repeatedly turned away when:

“I asked her if I could call her your name”

In an interview with NME, songwriter Alex Turner cited “Cornerstone” as one of the songs he’s most happy with, saying:

“‘Cornerstone’, maybe… it’s quite concise.”

This was reflected during Arctic Monkeys’ 2018 tour, where “Cornerstone” was performed at almost every concert.

In an interview with Uncut magazine, Turner shed some light on the writing process for “Cornerstone”, saying:

“I wrote ‘Cornerstone’ one morning, quite quickly. There’s something to be said for writing in the morning. At other points in the day you’re a bit more defensive. I saw it as a challenge to write something in a major key, but that wasn’t cheesy.”

Turner cites Yorkshire folk-pop artist Jake Thackray as an influence for “Cornerstone”. Thackray is known for his humorous and often sexually bizarre songs, as well as his affected vocals. With that reference in mind, it’s highly probable that the distinctive red polo neck sported by Turner in the music video for “Cornerstone” is to match the one worn by Thackray in this BBC Four broadcast of his song “Lah-Di-Dah”, the very song Turner mentions as a structural inspiration for “Cornerstone”.

Within the context of Humbug, “Cornerstone” is a musical diversion of sorts, thanks in part to its being written in a major key; a bright anomaly in a troupe of decidedly darker offerings.

songs.full_title: Mardy Bum by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Mardy Bum

description.plain:
A song from Arctic Monkeys' 2006 album Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not. It remains a fan favourite and helped popularise the Yorkshire word ‘mardy’, meaning sulky or uncooperative.

He argues with his girlfriend (or lover) who is simply not having it and being mardy with him; in the choruses he recollects the beginning of the relationship, comparing it to how moody she’s acting in the verses.

The charm of the song lies in the fact that there is no consoling a woman who has already made up her mind; i.e. who’s got the face on.

songs.full_title: When the Sun Goes Down by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: When the Sun Goes Down

description.plain:
The second single from Arctic Monkeys' debut album is about prostitution around the studio they were recording in in Sheffield. It was a considerable commercial success, scoring the band their second UK #1 single after “I Bet You Look Good on the Dancefloor” earlier that year.

The music video is the most literal they’ve done – a far cry from the videos they did with Richard Ayoade.

songs.full_title: I Bet You Look Good on the Dancefloor by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: I Bet You Look Good on the Dancefloor
songs.title_with_featured: I Bet You Look Good on the Dancefloor

description.plain:
The breakout and first single by Arctic Monkeys, from their debut album Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not.

It’s about seeing a girl in a mundane, everyday situation and wondering what she might look like on a night out.

The song was released on October 17, 2005. On its first day of release, I Bet You Look Good on the Dancefloor  sold over 120,000 UK copies on its first day of release.

description.plain:
Sometimes mistakenly referred to as “Brainstorm.”



When asked to say a little about the song’s protagonist, Alex Turner replied,

I can’t remember Brian now… I don’t know if he were in my imagination or what… it’s a blank spot in my brain… I think that’s what [Brian] wanted.

songs.full_title: A Certain Romance by Arctic Monkeys

description.plain: “A Certain Romance” is the last song on Arctic Monkeys first album, Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not, released in 2006. NME described it as “a strangely even-handed song, in which Alex Turner starts out scorning local townies then appears to absolve them at the end of the song,” and named it the 10th best track of the decade.

songs.full_title: Batphone by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Batphone

description.plain:
Track 10 off Arctic Monkeys' sixth studio album, Tranquility Base Hotel And Casino.

“Bat phone” is business jargon for a private phone line whose calls take priority over official channels. The term had its genesis in the late 1960s Batman television series.

The song speaks of technology, and gives both an analysis and criticism of modern day use of devices. Interestingly enough, songwriter Alex Turner doesn’t associate himself with any form of social media outside using Twitter for promotion and updates. He warned “technology is worth keeping an eye on” during his interview with Billboard promoting the upcoming album.

description.plain:
In “American Sports” Turner takes a look into the dystopian future, and compares present day obsessions to the habits of the moon’s fictional inhabitants.

This song’s narrative expands upon the strange imagery told throughout “Star Treatment”. However, while that song lamented introspectively, “American Sports” is very open and external.

songs.full_title: Piledriver Waltz by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Piledriver Waltz

description.plain: A song about heartbreak, “Piledriver Waltz” was originally written for the soundtrack of the movie Submarine, which features original songs written by Arctic Monkeys frontman Alex Turner. The title fits the theme of heart ache because ‘piledriver’ is a very painful wrestling move when it is being done to you; like that feeling that you’ve been punched in the stomach when someone breaks your heart. Alex has taken it a step further, then re-recorded for the album.

songs.full_title: From the Ritz to the Rubble by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: From the Ritz to the Rubble
songs.title_with_featured: From the Ritz to the Rubble

description.plain:
“From the Ritz to the Rubble” is the 12th song on Arctic Monkey’s first album, Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not.

Like many of the songs on the album, it follows a clubbing experience in Sheffield. In this song, Alex Turner gets turned away from a club and hooks up anyway.

“The Ritz” is a live music venue in Manchester. Since the bouncers are aggressive, Alex may be describing his journey through the lines at The Ritz to the rubble when a bouncer decides to “give him a duff.”

songs.full_title: She Looks Like Fun by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: She Looks Like Fun

description.plain:
Alex Turner, speaking to Pitchfork:

It’s about the characters that people create in that virtual world[social media].

This song is about how in the modern information age, everyone ends up being nasty to each other because of how people can share their unfiltered, often anonymous thoughts.

While it doesn’t seem like the song’s topic, it contains at least one reference to Alex’s girlfriend, Taylor Bagley, and her Instagram. Taylor seemed to quit Instagram in late January of 2018, probably because angry Arctic Monkeys fans began harassing her.

songs.full_title: Fake Tales of San Francisco by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Fake Tales of San Francisco

description.plain:
After being featured on the band’s debut album Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not, the song was released as a radio only single in the United States instead of “Leave Before the Lights Come On”, which was released there at the end of October.  The song was popular on alternative rock radio in the U.S. in late 2006, but ultimately did not chart on the Billboard Hot Modern Rock Tracks chart.

The song has been one of the band’s signature tracks, with its popularity as the band’s first recorded track. The song derides a fictional South Yorkshire band for taking its inspiration from the USA while never having been there, with lyrics such as “I’d love to tell you all my problem / You’re not from New York City, you’re from Rotherham”, and “He talks of San Francisco, he’s from Hunter’s Bar”. The song’s title, however, has made it a fan favorite in the United States.

This song describes people’s infatuation with their own devices, and how technology offers up ease of access while potentially making us dumber in the process.

The song is probably named after this headline, about Lee O'Donnell successfully accomplishing the world’s first monster truck front flip at the 2017 Monster Jam World Finals.

songs.full_title: Balaclava by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Balaclava

description.plain:
This song is about an affair. The woman is still on a relationship with another guy, hence the “before the hour is done”. And the cuckolding man is probably known by the cheaters, since there may be a skirmish to be found in.

The balaclava is essentially the mask that the man wears when hooking up with a woman in order for them both not to get emotionally attached and for it to remain just sex.

“The confidence is the balaclava,” hints that even though the man might be catching feelings, nothing will ever be revealed. Not to the woman by giving hope, and not to the man by hinting anything. After all, it’s just sex.

songs.full_title: Science Fiction by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Science Fiction

description.plain: Science fiction (the film and literary genre) uses otherworldly characters, events and situations to comment on our own world. This is what Arctic Monkeys do for much of this record, making this song somewhat of a mission statement for the album. The choruses point out three different things Turner wants to accomplish, and how science fiction does the same.

songs.full_title: My Propeller by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: My Propeller

description.plain:
It was released as the third single from the band’s third studio album Humbug, as announced on 1 February 2010. Released on 22 March 2010, the single follows its two predecessors from Humbug, “Crying Lightning” and “Cornerstone”, with the 10" vinyl being sold exclusively at Oxfam charity stores.

Originally, Arctic Monkeys planned the third single to be “Pretty Visitors”, but was switched to “My Propeller”.

songs.full_title: The Jeweller's Hands by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: The Jeweller’s Hands

description.plain:
The song is basically about the idea of having an affair. In an interview with Xfm, Alex Turner said that this song meaning was very similar to “Catapult”. In fact, in this song, just like in Catapult, the girl despite having a boyfriend feels completely attracted to a guy and ends up having an affair with him, which immediately leads her to an extreme regret.

Alex himself played all the keyboard parts. According to him, this is their first song where no guitar is played by him.

songs.full_title: Dance Little Liar by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Dance Little Liar

description.plain:
“Dance Little Liar” is a third-person narrative detailing the effect of a dishonest boyfriend on an unraveling relationship.

This is the song that convinced QOTSA frontman Josh Homme to invite the band into his desert studio Rancho de la Luna and push the Monkeys' sound in a new direction.

-Alex Turner

songs.full_title: This House is a Circus by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: This House is a Circus

description.plain:
Alex Turner’s favourite song on the album, “This House is a Circus” is the 8th track on the Arctic Monkeys' album Favourite Worst Nightmare. This track depicts the wild night life of a young rockstar, where lines become blurred and social etiquette becomes a vague memory. The song describes party/night life in a way that emphasizes the reality of what goes on outside one’s perception as a participant. The lacking memories, social embarrassments and imbibing all leads up to revealing admission of unfulfillment, revealing the emptiness and short lived pleasure of a wild night.

Like several of the other tracks on the album, the track is also musically much more ambitious than the group’s earlier work, using more intricate arrangements, heavy guitar tones and experimental song structure.

songs.full_title: Riot Van by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Riot Van

description.plain: The ideas behind many of the Arctic Monkey’s songs are laid out there pretty bluntly, but they always show an underlying idea or feeling behind the apparent storyline. In this it tells about a group of people who are just out to have fun, don’t really care much of what happens to them in life. As long as they had some good laughs, they don’t care if they are rich or have a job or are poor or anything. They just want to exist.

songs.full_title: Fire and the Thud by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Fire and the Thud

description.plain: During this song, the narrator is involved in a relationship with a girl that doesn’t return the same level of feelings as him. The narrator has an intense emotional attachment to this girl but to her she doesn’t see it as a long term deal. She inevitability breaks off the relationship and leaves the narrator heartbroken, even though he never saw the relationship lasting. After time has passed, the wound never fully heals and he tries to avoid the any memory of the relationship at all costs, never bringing it up in conversation to spare himself the pain. In the end, she followed through with the teasing of the fire that she threatened to start, with a thud.

The B Side to “I Bet That You Look Good On the Dancefloor”, this is a very English song about fickle teenage relationships and how it’s inevitable someone will try to steal your girl. The ‘bigger boys’ are in fact men with more worldly experience who prey on schoolgirls.

In an interview, Alex Turner jokingly said that if he died, he would like Lady Gaga to cover this song in memoriam.

songs.full_title: Perhaps Vampires Is a Bit Strong But... by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Perhaps Vampires Is a Bit Strong But...
songs.title_with_featured: Perhaps Vampires Is a Bit Strong But...

description.plain:
“Perhaps Vampires Is a Bit Strong But…” is a song from the Arctic Monkeys' debut album, wherein Alex talks about how people around the band didn’t believe in them. Here “Vampires” refers to the condescending people who stand by them but doesn’t believe in their ability. The people doesn’t understand that Alex and his mates didn’t start the band to earn money, but to be themselves. Matt and Alex described this in an interview:

Alex: It’s like when this time last year we were just doing gigs everywhere and we were having conversations with people, like neighbours and stuff.
Matt: They’re all like “How much’d you get paid for that?” when they had a few beers in and that. You should get down the working mens clubs, 400 a turn on a Saturday night.

songs.full_title: The Bakery by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: The Bakery

description.plain:
B-side to “Fluorescent Adolescent” off of Favourite Worst Nightmare.

The song details the loneliness and issues of faceless girls at shows. Considering the time of release, it was probably written hot off the heels of a world tour – a life totally removed from his one two years ago.

In some ways, this is almost the reversal of “You Couldn’t See For the Lights…” on their first record. Every night, he’s in a new town looking out to a new audience. And every night there’s a pretty young thing looking back at him. Nothing could ever happen, so he fantasises about seeing them in an inane setting, without his band. However, Alex is a realist: if it weren’t for the band, she never would’ve given him the time of day.

songs.full_title: Potion Approaching by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Potion Approaching

description.plain:
“Potion Approaching” is Arctic Monkeys' 5th single from their 3rd studio album, Humbug. It was first released on 19 August, 2009 by Domino Records. The band started to write songs for the album towards the end of summer 2008, and finished it entirely in spring 2009.

Humbug has been considered a very important piece in Arctic Monkeys' catalogue. It marked the first time they recorded material under Queens of The Stone Age frontman, Josh Homme’s, influence. In an article by NME magazine, Mike Williams writes:

If Arctic Monkeys had never walked into the desert with Josh Homme to record Humbug in 2009, they could never have made AM‘. Humbug was as much about subverting people’s impressions of who the band were as it was an album in its own right.

songs.full_title: Baby I'm Yours by Arctic Monkeys (Ft. 747s)
songs.title: Baby I’m Yours

description.plain:
“Baby I’m Yours” is a song written by Van McCoy which was a hit in 1965 for Barbara Lewis (US) and Peter & Gordon (UK).

In 2006, “Baby I’m Yours” served as the B-side of Arctic Monkeys' UK hit “Leave Before the Lights Come On” (#4); that version featured the 747’s with shared vocals by Arctic Monkeys' lead singer Alex Turner and the 747s' lead singer Oisin Leech.

The track is credited to the “Newell Octet” on the vinyl release.

songs.full_title: Red Right Hand by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Red Right Hand

description.plain:
Ever wanted to sell your soul to the Devil? This song is an extremely accurate account on why it may seem attractive, but you shouldn’t do it.

Originally a song by Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds, Red Right Hand was performed during the Humbug era and released as a B-side to Crying Lighting.

songs.full_title: Brick by Brick by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Brick by Brick

description.plain:
This is the first album song where the agile beast himself, drummer Matt Helders, takes over the lead vocals.

Turner explained the process behind this song in his 5-10-15-20 interview with Pitchfork:

I read this story about Iggy Pop where he said there was a TV show he used to watch when he was young, and the guy would ask kids to write letters into the show, and the letters had to be less than 25 words– and he applied that to writing “No Fun”. So, since we always do songs with a thousand words, we thought we should try one that had less than 30, which turned out to be “Brick by Brick”. But I got the drummer to sing it because it seemed like the right thing to do.

songs.full_title: 2013 by Arctic Monkeys

description.plain: Coming as the B-Side to “Do I Wanna Know?,” the lead single off Arctic Monkeys fifth studio album, AM, “2013” is a surprisingly straightforward song on modern technology, with a psychedelic 60s vibe. Turner seems to reach back to his early days of songwriting, ditching the complex lyricism seen on recent albums for a simpler topic which he tackles in a tongue and cheek manner.

songs.full_title: - by Arctic Monkeys

description.plain:
The band visited the famous Electric Lady Studios in New York to take part in the Spotify Singles series, where an original and a cover is recorded.

The band chose the untitled closing track “—” from Stephen Fretwell’s 2004 record Magpie.

Fretwell and Alex Turner have been linked for many years – Fretwell played bass on a 2008 tour with Turner’s side project The Last Shadow Puppets, and as far as back as 2005, Fretwell exclaimed his love for Arctic Monkeys, describing them as “pretty crazy live”.

songs.full_title: You and I by Arctic Monkeys (Ft. Richard Hawley)
songs.title: You and I

description.plain:
An awesome duet between the two darlings of Sheffield, The Monkeys and Hawley paint a picture of a tough guy in trouble with love.

The result is one of the hardest songs either act has ever done, and a blues tinged masterpiece included only on the B-Side of Black Treacle.

The song was credited to “Richard Hawley and the Death Ramps”, the Death Ramps being an alias of the Arctic Monkeys first used in 2007 on the Teddy Picker EP.

songs.full_title: I Haven't Got My Strange by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: I Haven’t Got My Strange

description.plain:
Third track on the single Crying Lightning.

This song is one of Alex Turner’s lyrical masterpieces. The line “I had a hole in the pocket of my favourite coat and my love dropped into the lining” is beyond clever it boggles the mind. The line “You can’t sleep until you’ve sat on the steps to weep until you feel like you’ve wept” just put Turner above all great lyricists, he just dove to the bottom of the pacific ocean my friends, that was DEEP. Absolutely unbelievable.

songs.full_title: I.D.S.T. by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: I.D.S.T.

description.plain:
I.D.S.T. is the third track on the single Don’t Sit Down Cause I’ve Moved Your Chair.

The song has very little content but the meaning and connotation is present in full force. Using simple examples, Alex Turner is able to convey the idea that break ups do not remove all the memories of the relationship, they will always be present in the mind.

songs.full_title: If You Found This It's Probably Too Late by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: If You Found This It’s Probably Too Late
songs.title_with_featured: If You Found This It's Probably Too Late

description.plain:
Alex isn’t “sure we’re ready”, since the second album was pretty soon after the first (Exactly 1 year after the Who the Fuck EP, actually).

He thinks people will say the new stuff is rubbish and “nothing on the early stuff” – a common phrase from music “fans” who don’t like the new output of a band and say “the old stuff was better” etc. etc. Arctic Monkeys aren’t suffering from the “Sophomore Slump” on their second release.

In a vaguely related note, this song might have opened the album. Matt said they thought about opening the album with something silly like strings but they decided just to go the no-nonsense route and just start with Brianstorm instead.

songs.full_title: Still Take You Home (Demo) by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Still Take You Home (Demo)

description.plain:
A demo version of “Still Take You Home”, on the collection of old demos “Beneath The Boardwalk”. This track was later redone for Arctic Monkey’s debut album “Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not”

This version has multiple differences to the 2006 release. The first and third verses have different lyrics, there is also an instrumental break before both the 2nd verse and the bridge. This song, alone with many of their demos feature a rougher singing voice, with Alex yelling multiple times throughout the track.

songs.full_title: BRITs Acceptance Speech 2014 by Alex Turner (Ft. Arctic Monkeys)
songs.title: BRITs Acceptance Speech 2014

description.plain:
The speech cause quite a stir in early 2014. Reactions to the speech were mixed but one thing most everyone can agree on is that it comes off better on the page, than the way Alex actually delivered it.

Worth the watch just for the other band-mates reactions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cEVkt0fLWKA

songs.embed_content: Read “BRITs Acceptance Speech 2014” by Alex Turner on Genius

annotatable.link_title: BRITs Acceptance Speech 2014 by Alex Turner (Ft. Arctic Monkeys)
annotatable.title: BRITs Acceptance Speech 2014

body.plain:
The speech cause quite a stir in early 2014. Reactions to the speech were mixed but one thing most everyone can agree on is that it comes off better on the page, than the way Alex actually delivered it.

Worth the watch just for the other band-mates reactions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cEVkt0fLWKA

songs.lyrics:
BRITs Acceptance Speech 2014 Lyrics"That rock 'n'roll, eh? That rock'n'roll, it just won't go away. It might hibernate from time to time, and sink back into the swamp. I think the cyclical nature of the universe in which it exists demands it adheres to some of its rules.
But it's always waiting there, just around the corner. Ready to make its way back through the sludge and smash through the glass ceiling, looking better than ever. Yeah, that rock'n'roll, it seems like it's faded away sometimes, but it will never die. And there's nothing you can do about it."
Thank you very much for this. I do truly appreciate it. Don't take that the wrong way. And er... Yeah. Invoice me for the microphone if you need to.5Embed

songs.full_title: Riot Van (Demo) by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Riot Van (Demo)

description.plain:
An earlier version of the song which also featured on their debut album. This was part of their earlier collection of music was was distributed over the file-sharing websites pre-2006.

A great descriptive piece with classic Turner lyrics about a standard night out in Sheffield for any teenager, looking for trouble to kill some time. However, this version of the song has a darker ending. A car is stolen but then crashes, ending with the death of the kids in the car, rather than the album version where they were just harassed by the cops and then were let go.

This cover is featured on the “All The Rage” album released by Domino Records in 2008 which includes tracks from various artists including: Sons & Daughters, Stephen Malkmus and Cass McCombs.

songs.full_title: Come Together by Arctic Monkeys
songs.title: Come Together

description.plain:
Originally written by John Lennon released in
September 26, 1969 for the album Abbey Road. Arctic Monkeys covered the classic song for the Opening Ceremony of  2012’s London Olympic Games.

The song was suppose to be a campaign song for Timothy Leary  (advocate for the use of psychedelics like LSD who was running for California Governor. However was deemed inappropriate getting released as The Beatles own original material. Becoming a staple to one of the biggest bands of all time and covered by numerous artists.

As I inhale the fumes

I push into the middle, the sound becomes a part of me

Watching my adrenaline rise, I feel the eyes on me
Sip the bottle now, don't be slow
Keep up with me as we lose control
Keep up with me as we lose control
As we erupt into the room
I feel the sub go boom
A feeling easy to resume
This right here, I swear, will end too soon
Sink in to the tune
As I inhale the fumes
A feeling easy to resume1Embed

annotatable.link_title: Arctic Monkeys - How We Wrote ‘I Bet You Look Good On The Dancefloor’ by NME (Ft. Alex Turner & Arctic Monkeys)
annotatable.title: Arctic Monkeys - How We Wrote 'I Bet You Look Good On The Dancefloor'

body.plain: Arctic Monkeys' debut single scored highly in our list of the 150 best songs of NME.COM’s lifetime. In this blog-cam video, Alex Turner explains how the song came about, and why lyrically it contains a few “stinkers”.

songs.lyrics:
Arctic Monkeys - How We Wrote ‘I Bet You Look Good On The Dancefloor’ LyricsAlex Turner:
I did find like the lyrics for it like not long ago like scribbled on like a piece of paper, it was quite funny
Like find like the -
(Was there any different changes?)
Oh yea, like loads, yeah they were all sort of stuff about like cigarettes and stuff, I don't know but erm
(Not any you regretted not putting in there now?)
No no no, they were all, there were some stinkers in there
Arguably there still is but erm
(Laughing)
They, erm, it was... can't remember, I can remember recording it like the first time we did it
Well cause we did it with this guy Alan Smyth in Sheffield, that we did like a lot, like all his first sort of recordings with
And there was this version of it, and then when we started like, we started this first record with
Like when we were beginning to sort of proper make the record,
We started with James Ford and this guy Mike Crossey, in Liverpool
And we had like a week and we'd been on tour and we play- we recorded like ten songs in a week or somet
And we were like "this is it! we've gon- done his album"
Y'know
"Fucking put it out tomorrow please, yesterday if you can"
And erm
But everything was kinda recorded at like, did it on tape and played everything at like 300 miles an hour
And it were like, it kinda, bit too like live or something I don't know
And at that point, it was suggested to us that perhaps we'd like try a different avenue so then we went back with this producer called Jim Abbiss
And went to a studio in Lincoln
And er, and sorta, y'know sorta, recording...
But y'know going through the songs and like listening to the demos
And sorta tryna, you know, pick the best bits about and whatever
Cause everyone were kinda really into these demos of it
So we sorta wanted to get a bit of that but kinda like a better recording of it
It was weird cause when we were... recording that tune
The video was already like on telly for it
Like cause w- people'd be like watching TV in't other room like "ahh quick we're on we're on MTV or whatever"
Cause like the v- the version we did for the video
Like we just made another recording like it's just us playing like a TV studio or whatever and-
(It was a live thing wasn't it? The video was telling a live performance)
Yeah that version of it was just like there and then
So it's weird like we were tryna cut this single in one room
And it was like on telly in like the other room like us
"Erm, yeah, just use that"
But erm, but no we did it with, er, did it again, yeah did it there with Jamie like in, in Lincoln
And then that became the... version
But it all came from that like drum thing on the beginning, you know like the, I mean originally, that was like the
What was like the first part of that song, was like that kinda drum thing
(Can you remember sorta coming up with the guitar bit and all that stuff? was that you? was that cookie or?)
I play like the lead on it yeah, and like this sorta cord thing, not really, I can't really, can't remember, what, when that happened or what even like, what practice room we were in at that time really but
I remember Matt playing that thing round, cause I think I guess it was like some exercise or something he'd like seen somewhere or like a version of it which he'd like sped up or somet and he were like doing it as fast as he could and then
Like a lot of them songs, like then, used to come from something like that he'd play
(Really?)
He almosts like plays, like riffs on drums sometimes or whatever, or plays like leads or somet so
(What does it mean to you now that song? at this moment in time)
It's like more fun than ever to play it now
Like I think I probably fell out with it for a, for a moment like somewhere along the way
But I kinda
Yeah I fell out with eve-
I fall out with all of them at some point, but that's definitely one that like
I'd never imagine like not playing it
And now when it kinda comes round in sets, it's just like, fun y'know
Like that's it
It's erm
Yeah no we all sorta really enjoy playing that
And it's one of them you can like
Cause some of the other songs we've written since then I guess are a bit more like complex and you have to kinda concentrate a little bit more
And like think about singing in tune and like playing the right notes
And that one...
(Yeah)
You can sorta, just like have a laugh with... few minutes
(Oh cool)
Still manage to murder it sometimes though, it kinda feels like a lot of them older tunes
We don't play a lot of them because it feels like you can't anymore, like whatever it took to sorta write and like play them songs when we used to, 'int' there anymore
And for some reason, some of them have a longer shelf life than other ones
Or it sorta sometimes feel like we're doing like covers of-
It feels like they're cover songs that we play like
(Really?)
But we kinda can't do a cover of Fake Tales of San Francisco but I think we do a pl- a pretty good I Bet You Look Good On The Dancefloor cover.Embed

Sandtrap Lyrics
When you leave us through the patient doors

Oh, the nasty laughter and desperate smirks
Are tangled in the boredom where our brittle kisses lurk
Well, how can I believe you when you can't believe your luck?

And the shards of past attraction lie visible but shy
And blunt and weak and worn
Away by whining in the emery paper voice you use to speak
Oh, the shards of past attraction lie visible but shy
And blunt and weak and worn
Away by whining in the emery paper voice you use to speak

In the trap
You only want to be the first to laugh
You only want to be the first in the sandtrap
You only want to be the first to laugh


And your climbing holes and cinder claws
Ring out like the calenture that you sent us all towards
Farewell, farewell, farewellEmbed
